boardgame.name: Dark Inheritance (Spycraft)
boardgame.description:
From Back Cover:



What Secrets Will You Uncover...

Ungodly horrors crawl within an abandoned gene-splicing lab and deadly wonders lay hidden beneath a murdered city, shattered by a catastrophe that defies explanation. But mankind's most primordial secret has already been discovered and brutally suppressed. The truth was never out there: it was inside each and every one of us, only waiting to be unlocked.

And you hold the key.

Now, you can unleash the secrets of the Lost Age. Harness powerful supernatural forces in a world sixty seconds into a terrifying future. Outwit and outfight secret societies and black book government agencies for control of your destiny.

But watch your back. As the dust settles, a forgotten enemy slips through the cracks in their eternal prison, escaping onto streets lined with grass and steel. This world was once theirs, and they want it back!

The world is up for grabs, with the smartest, fastest, and toughest making their plays - winner takes all!



...Or Die To Protect?

Dark Inheritance is the newest Spycraft™ campaign, featuring:

An action packed world where the mysteries and terrors of the supernatural collide with the crises of modern events and technology.
Choose your style of play! Sign on with the NSA black program Project: TITAN; run with the criminal but enlightened Eight Heavenly Dragons triad; uncover the terrible truth with the International Geographical Society; or join one of four other exciting agencies. Each faction is fully detailed and has its own spin on action!
Three all new base classes and five new prestige classes. Play a determined Advocate, knowledgeable Arcanist, a cutting edge Genesoldier, a dynamic Two-Fisted God of Guns, or four other unique classes!
Harness the powers of magic - a complete system to utilize magic from your fantasy d20™ products in the Spycraft™ system!
Play a titan, a hero born with the genetic legacy of ancient gods or monsters. Pick from five distinct lineages and over 150 powers from a lost age!
Enter an ancient world, once locked behind eldritch gates and filled with monsters out of legend, an Otherworld waiting to be explored.
Challenge players with your own diabolical cults, who covet power gained through blood sacrifice.

boardgame.name: Circle Search
boardgame.description:
A Decktet memory game for two children.

From the Decktet wiki:

On your turn, declare "I am searching for ..." and name the suit from one of the unclaimed aces. Then move your token one card clockwise and turn over the card your token lands on, revealing it for everyone to see. If that card has the suit you were searching for, claim the ace of that suit - unless it was a Crown, which causes you to put back in the middle of the table the claimed ace of the Crown's suit if you have currently claimed it. The excuse does nothing when one of the face-down cards.

The younger player goes first, unless the game was just played and someone one, in which case the previous game's loser goes first. Players take turns until all six aces are claimed. The player who claims the most aces wins. If both players claim three aces the game is a draw.

In Corundum, this game is called 'Conundrum Terrapin'. This may be because, as in Terrapin, something happens when every suit is present in a group of cards. People outside Corundum call the game 'Corundum Conundrum' - except the tongue-tied Bhargivians, who call it 'Conungrem'.

Conundrum is a partnership trick-taking game for the Decktet for 4 in teams of 2 sitting opposite each other. The goal of the game is to take the most cards possible in the most tricks possible.

boardgame.name: Battle of the River Plate
boardgame.description:
Three Royal Navy cruisers encounter the German pocket battleship Admiral Graf Spee off the eastern coast of South America, December 13, 1939.

"Battle of the River Plate" is a realistic tactical wargame of WW2 ship vs. ship naval combat for two players. A Minden Games revised zip-lock edition of the Graf Spee wargame which appeared in Panzerschreck magazine #13. Provides new ship ratings, and introduces new rules and modifications congruent with the Battleship Captain standard game system.

Battleship Captain is a "miniatures" game system with scenarios played on the tabletop or floor, using the rules and ship counters provided. The game emphasizes playability, as players maneuver their ships and try and defeat the enemy fleet. Historical scenarios range in size from small (such as River Plate and Denmark Strait), which have only four or five ships to large (such as Tsushima and Jutland), which involve dozens of ships.

The game also requires tape measure or ruler in inches, paper and pencil, and a six-sided die.

--from the published game and the Minden Games web site

boardgame.name: Supremacy Wars
boardgame.description:
Developers Cave of Wonders Studios and Alcomi bring Supremacy Wars to the App Store: a super fun, fast-paced Strategy Game that requires tactics and quick thinking. Choose a civilization and upgrade its inhabitants’ skills as you play. Use skills and cast spells to defeat a variety of enemies, including some pretty huge monsters! Supremacy Wars has a deep and engaging story with well polished and colorful visuals and a unique artistic style. There’s hours upon hours of fun to be had, with over 90 levels, 150 achievements and an amazing eight game modes!

Choose your Civilization: There are three different races to choose from and plenty of levels for each, as well as an interesting and deeply engaging storyline. Upgrade the skill sets of your characters along the way.

Deep Tactics: Supremacy Wars incorporates an easy to use and yet exceptionally deep tactics system. Players will need to think carefully and quickly if they are to defeat their enemies.

Replay Value: With three civilizations to choose from and over 90 levels, there is an enormous amount of play time. Include the immense variety of games available, the skills and spells to try out, and all 150 achievements and there’s a huge amount of replay value in Supremacy Wars.

Crystal Leaderboards and Achievements: Players can earn achievements and compare scores with online leaderboards through Crystal!

boardgame.name: Warlords Battlecry 2
Warlords Battlecry 2
Warlords: Battlecry II
boardgame.description:
Primarily a real-time strategy game, the main objective of Warlords Battlecry II is to build up a base and army in order to fight enemies. A game will usually end when all but one of the players has been defeated, although there are some minor differences depending on which victory condition is selected. Most buildings and units are created by spending resources, while some buildings and units can also be summoned by certain units.

There are twelve different playable races, each with its own strengths, weaknesses and resource dependencies. There are roughly a hundred and forty controllable units which will fight and, in some cases, build buildings.

The game also features some basic role-playing elements including leveling-up characters and completing optional quests. In addition to these units, the player controls a Hero which they have created before playing. The Hero is a unique unit which, as well as being able to fight and build buildings, can cast spells and receive quests. Depending on the outcome of a battle, the Hero will receive experience points and level up, as is common in many role-playing games.

There are two main game modes: the campaign and skirmish mode. The campaign is non-linear, with a goal of conquering the entire continent of Etheria (the land in which the game is set). Skirmish games can be played against computer-controlled enemies and other human players. All the game modes and victory conditions available in the campaign are playable, as well as some multiplayer-only modes. The game also comes with a level editor.

Source: Wikipedia, "Warlords Battlecry II", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

boardgame.name: Coin Rail Yard
boardgame.description:
Coin Rail Yard is a Solitaire game (1 player) where the player will take on the duties of the yardmaster for the game's Rail Yard. The player will operate the Locomotives which will break-down arriving Trains and build-up departing Trains.
The player will run through one of the sixteen scenarios, keeping track of how many turns that it took to complete the day's work. The final score will be determined by the number of turns plus any penalty occurred for mistakes.
There is a small amount of randomness in the game. There is also some flexibility in how the rail cars are arranged in the yard before the first Train arrives. This randomness and flexibility means that a scenario need not play out the same way the second time through. The game also comes with the guidelines for how to generate your own scenarios.
Several expansion maps are planned.

boardgame.name: Hulk Hogan's Rock 'n' Wrestling Card Game
boardgame.description:
Hulk Hogan's Rock 'n' Wrestling Card Game is a game in which players try to improve their hand of cards by drawing the top card of either the face-down draw pile or the face-up discard pile, and discarding either that card or one of the four cards in their hand. Except for Flip cards, each card has a point value in the range of 3 to 10, or 0. If a player discards a Flip card when they do not have the advantage, then they take the advantage from the other player. Only the player with the advantage is able to call a Showdown, at which time both sides reveal their hands; the player with the highest point total wins the match.

The four-player game plays much like the two-player game, with the major difference being that the player who calls for a Showdown must beat the hands of both of his opponents.

boardgame.name: Time of Wrath
World War 2: Time of Wrath
World War II: Time of Wrath
boardgame.description:
Diplomacy has failed, tyranny is on the march, now is the Time of Wrath!

From the front lines in France and Russia to the deserts of North Africa and the airfields and convoys of Britain, the campaigns of World War II are yours to command in WW2: Time of Wrath! This turn-based grand strategy title, the highly improved and expanded sequel to WW2: Road to Victory, puts the player in charge of the political, economic and military decisions of one or more Axis or Allied nations, including minor nations. A diplomacy system based on political points allows you to sway possible allies to your side. An upgraded and expanded naval combat system includes fleet engagements, combat patrols, massive aircraft carriers, elusive raiders and U-Boats as well as a convoy system.

Concentrate precious industrial resources on building, training and upgrading a wide variety of combat units from airborne soldiers and armored divisions up to nuclear weapons! Historical leaders enhance the performance of your armies and hundreds of historical events like the Molotov-Ribbentrop Pact, Lend-Lease and more give you choices that can change the course of history. WW2: Time of Wrath is fought across turns that vary in length by season and 25 km hexes with divisions and corps, giving the player a broad strategic picture of the war while still leaving enough room for operational decisions.

Source: The Publisher Website.


Time of Wrath gives a fine piece of wargaming for every fan of ww2 era. This strategy allows players to take control over any country during World War 2 era in Europe and North Africa theater. It was designed in a way which allows players who are new to the genre to quickly familiarize with the rules and to start battles with veterans who still remember great classic strategy titles.

Easy rules, deep historical setting and detailed OOB, together with great moddability potential will allow for hundreds of hours of gameplay as any nation or even a whole alliance.

Features

- Europe and North Africa 1939-1948.
- More than 20000 Land Hexes.
- Over 30 countries.
- Weekly Strategic Turns.
- Simplified economic system allowing to focus on military operations.
- Air and Land Combat, including Sieges, Interceptions, Strategic Bombardment, Air Recon, Fleet Air attacks, Bombardment.
- Naval system allowing to build Aircraft Carriers, Battle, Patrol and Submarine Groups. Managing fleets, convoys and raiders in Sea Zones.
- Possible to play as any nation and as any combination of countries.
- Diplomacy focused on three main alliances: Axis. Allies and Commitern. Diplomatic actions allow to haste or slow down war entry, perform elections or Coup.
- Weather system simulates, spring and autumns rainfalls and snow. Beware of General Frost!
- Logistics system controlling supply level of all units.
- Customizable Fog of War, that might be revealed by air recon.
- Hot-seat and PBEM.
- Standard Campaign from 1939 - 1948 as well as other starting campaigns to diverse starting possibilities.
- Hundreds of historical events such as Molotov-Ribbentrop Pact, Vienna Dictate, Lend-Lease, and many more.
- Map zooms in and out smoothly.
- Technological race in research of new more powerful units and control power of Atomic bomb.
- Fully historical, detailed orders of battle in all scenarios with historical names for hundreds of land, air and naval units.
- Land units divided into Divisional and Corps size allows to choose tactic of steamroller or maneuvers warfare.
- Possibility to create modern or obsolete units.
- Improved A.I. to perform better in strategic and tactical level.
- Hotkeys allowing for quick access to most important functionalities.
- Mulberry harbors as a helpful and powerful tool in preparation to huge landing operations.
- Paratroopers will help to takeover distant key point locations.
- Music that aids immersion into the game atmosphere.
- Historical commanders boosting commanded units.
- Suez and Gibraltar as an important locations helping to control Mediterranean.
- Customized graphic for major countries units.
- Borders editor together with easy access to game data files allows to change and setup own scenarios.

Source: The Game Website.

boardgame.name: La Via Delle Armi: Supplemento #3
boardgame.description:
From the Italian Introduction:

Pax Imperialis

I conflitti armati su grande scala restano assai rari nell'Impero, per molte ragioni. Più evidente di tutte è l'uso generalizzato dello Scudo Holtzman che rende inutili la maggior parte delle armi che operano a distanza. A questa limitazione di ordine tecnologico si aggiungono un certo numero di costrizioni politico giuridiche (le leggi della Grande Convenzione), o economiche (mantenere un esercito costa estremamente caro, farlo trasportare da un mondo all'altro ancora di più...).


User Translation from Italian:

Imperial Peace

Large-scale armed conflicts are very rare in the Empire, for many reasons. Most obvious of all is the widespread use of the Holtzman Shield that would render most ranged weapons unusable. To this technological limitation there are in addition a number of political and legal constraints (the laws of the Great Convention) or economic constraints (to maintain an army is extremely expensive, to transport it from one world to another even more so...).

boardgame.name: Close Combat: Modern Tactics
boardgame.description:
Challenge yourself with the latest Close Combat release. Close Combat: Modern Tactics for the PC. Developed from the United States Marine Corps training simulation, Close Combat: Marines, you take command of modern US forces or various opposition forces in one of 25 scenarios included with the release.

Engage in combat with with up to 5 players per side and participate in intense head to head battles using Modern Era weaponry and equipment on gorgeous hand-drawn maps measuring from 1km square to giant 4km x 1km maps. Fight on hypothetical battlefields ranging in style from backwoods America to the streets of Iraq and the former Soviet republics. You face all the enemy can throw at you in a series of immersive, action-packed engagements that will test your tactical abilities! Air and artillery support are on-call but the final objective can only be secured by Close Combat.

A scenario editor is also included, making it easy to setup your own battles with modern opposing forces.

Source: The Publisher Website.

boardgame.name: Call of Cthulhu: The Card Game – Curse of the Jade Emperor Asylum Pack
La Llamada de Cthulhu: El Juego de Cartas – La Maldición del Emperador de Jade
boardgame.description:
Description from the publisher:

The Great Old Ones' insidious reach continues to spread and Curse of the Jade Emperor, the second Asylum Pack of the Ancient Relics cycle, follows the tendrils of evil into the Far East. Prepare for restless dead, secret societies, and unholy artifacts!

Ancient Relics is based on the theme of the global influence of the Ancient Ones and their cults and moves the action from H.P. Lovecraft's dread-filled New England to the wider world. In Curse of the Jade Emperor players will find exotic, yet hauntingly familiar characters and tales, pulled from the myths and legends of ancient China. The Middle Kingdom's undying past collides with a present made all the more uncertain through the interference of diverse otherworldly actors.

The pull of China is strong and in Call of Cthulhu it attracts academics from Miskatonic University, eager to study the history and artifacts of one of the world's oldest civilizations. The forces of law and order also come to do battle with some of the world's deadliest criminal organizations. Curse of the Jade Emperor also follows Ancient Relics' over-arching theme of artifacts with great and terrible power reoccurring throughout history. Pack your bags for a voyage to the Orient in Curse of the Jade Emperor!

boardgame.name: Call of Cthulhu: The Card Game – Conspiracies of Chaos Asylum Pack
La Llamada de Cthulhu: El Juego de Cartas – Conspiraciones del Caos
boardgame.description:
Description from the publisher:

Secrets and mysteries abound in a classic Asylum Pack, which is emerging from the shadows to crawl back into the light. Conspiracies of Chaos, the fifth Asylum Pack in the Forgotten Lore cycle of expansions for Call of Cthulhu: The Card Game, returns!

Conspiracies of Chaos reintroduces to the Living Card Game environment this intriguing Asylum Pack, updated to the 60-card per pack format (three copies each of 20 unique cards). The included cards have been updated to incorporate the most recent FAQ. In addition, the text on a number of cards has been altered from its original printing, adjusting for game balance and rules clarity.

Among Conspiracies of Chaos' features are six faction-specific conspiracies. Conspiracies are story cards that players can play from their own decks and win to further their goal of claiming three stories. The six conspiracies included within Conspiracies of Chaos play into one of each faction’s particular strengths. Also featured are an assortment of characters that thrive in a world of conspiracy–characters that grow stronger when a conspiracy is in play. In addition, this Asylum Pack also includes support cards and events that can wildly alter the tempo of the game.

boardgame.name: Charlie and the Chocolate Factory
Charlie und die Schokoladen-Fabrik
Charlie y la Fábrica de Chocolate
Sjakie en de Chocoladefabriek
boardgame.description:
Charlie and the Chocolate Factory is a 2005 video game which was released on the Xbox, PlayStation 2, Nintendo GameCube, Game Boy Advance, and Windows platforms. It is based on the film of the same name by Tim Burton. The game was released in the middle of the year to coincide with the release of the film in theatres. Most of the main cast from the film provided their voices for the game except for Johnny Depp, and James Arnold Taylor was used in his place as the voice of Willy Wonka.

Original Music for the video game was created by Winifred Phillips and produced by Winnie Waldron.

The first objective of the game is to help Charlie find money to buy a Wonka Bar to win a Golden Ticket. This is done at the beginning of the game while giving a tutorial of what controls will be needed during future stages.

The main part of the game takes place in Willy Wonka's chocolate factory where the Oompa Loompas help the player through each level. By giving them commands Charlie finishes each challenge and progresses through the game. Each Oompa Loompa specializes in different tasks, such as electrical work, harvesting and welding. Candy is scattered throughout the levels and when collected it boosts Charlie's energy.

Each level is very similar to the plot in the 2005 movie. For example, Charlie must help Willy Wonka remove the gluttonus Augustus Gloop from the pipe above the chocolate river. He must roll the blueberry Violet Beauregarde to the Juicing Room and juice her. When Veruca Salt is thrown down the garbage chute, the player's objective is to follow her down the chute and save her from the incinerator. The last objective of the game is after Mike Teavee shrinks himself the player needs to fix the television-chocolate machine. Throughout the game the Oompa Loompas must help Charlie return the chocolate factory back to normal by fixing the mistakes that the self-indulgent children made.

Source: Wikipedia, "Charlie and the Chocolate Factory (video games)", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

boardgame.name: Turtle Soup
boardgame.description:
A press-your-luck game of fraught cuisine for the Decktet.

Flip a card face up and then flip another. Continue until there are cards showing four or more of the six Decktet suits.

Active players simultaneously indicate whether they intend to take a bowl now or wait for more ingredients.

If the additional card makes it so that the face up cards include at least one instance of each of the six Decktet suits, then the soup has gone Turtle Butt. The soup night is over. Return any chips in the pot to the bank. Players who didn't take a bowl get nothing for that night.

The game should be played for at least five soup nights. Obviously, you can make the game longer by playing more nights. In the end, each small chip collected is worth 1 point and each large chip is worth 5. The player with the most points wins.

boardgame.name: Ziggurat Demolition Throwdown
boardgame.description:
Because the world needs more games about dueling wizards.

You are an ancient and powerful wizard living in a community for aged but powerful wizards. The guy across the way bubbles his cauldron much too loud, even though you have asked him to turn it down several times. There was a time when those who disturbed your afternoon tea would feel the force of your eldritch wrath. Perhaps this afternoon will be such a time.

The uses a copy of the Decktet and one Rainbow Pyramid stash for each player. (That's a small, medium, and large pyramid in each of five colours: Red, Yellow, Green, Blue, and Black. Two players can play with an Ice Dice set or two Treehouse sets.) Cards represent spells you have in mind; in the game, this means attacks you can make. Pyramids are your circle of magical instruments; they are what you need to have in place to play cards. Your opponent will whittle away at your pyramids, and you at theirs. The first player to run out of pyramids loses.

boardgame.name: Who is The Doctor?: Demon's Run Standoff
boardgame.description:
‘Demons run when a good man goes to war.’
This is an unauthorised, non-profit, print-and-play game inspired by the BBC TV show Doctor Who episode ‘A Good Man Goes to War’ (Series 6, Episode 7). The basic game mechanism is a kind of reverse werewolf/mafia game where the secret character, The Doctor, is the only person who can’t kill anyone and has to survive on wits and confusion alone.

Background: (Or buy the DVD and watch it!)
Human soldiers and the mysterious headless monks are working together in an uneasy alliance. They have kidnapped The Doctor’s companion (Amy Pond) and taken her to the asteroid know a Demon’s Run. The Doctor arrives on the asteroid disguised as one of the monks but reveals himself and demands Amy’s return. The lights go out and then back on, all orchestrated by the doctor, of course. Now the soldiers are stood there facing the monks. The soldiers know that one of the monks is their feared enemy, The Doctor, determined to foil their plans. All they have to do is to work out which monk is The Doctor in disguise and shoot him before he escapes. But if they shoot the wrong monk they will feel the wrath of their allies and be killed themselves by the monks dying blast. The monks themselves know that the soldiers are trigger happy and might shoot them. It might be best for them to zap any of the trigger happy soldiers before they themselves are killed - at least the other soldiers would know that they were a monk and not The Doctor. But the monks’ plan needs the soldiers and if they lose all of their soldiers then their plans will fail and The Doctor will triumph. The soldiers and monks need to act quickly before The Doctor is able to escape. The scene is set for the Demon’s Run Standoff.

The Game:
The players take on the role of soldiers, headless monks and The Doctor through a series of standoffs. During each standoff: the soldiers try to kill The Doctor; the monks try to direct the soldiers to The Doctor, and The Doctor just tries to survive. At the end of the standoff, points are given to players whose characters are still alive.

boardgame.description:
User Summary

Jamestown (Legend of the Lost Colony) is "a neo-classical top-down shooter for up to four players, set on 17th-century British Colonial Mars" [as defined by its official website].

Its style is similar to classic arcades ("handcrafted pixels") and the action is like many shoot-'em-up, but it features an inventive story, 4 different types of playable ships and (local) multiplayer for up to 4 people on the screen at once.
Various "extras" are all included (different difficulty levels, secret scenarios, unlockable ships, etc.).

It received a "honorable mention for Excellence in Audio" during Independent Games Festival 2011.

boardgame.name: Super Conflict
Super Conflict: The Mideast
boardgame.description:
Super Conflict: The Mideast is a Super NES turn-based video game where the player is a commissioned army officer and he has to command his troops to victory during a fictional Gulf War-like combat situation. The blue forces are armed with American weapons while the red forces are armed with Soviet-made weapons. As the game progresses the player is able to control air and naval units.

Super Conflict is played on a hex map in which players try to capture the opponent's "Flag Tank" or "Flag Ship". The map consists of various terrain tiles with movement and defense modifiers. For example, bridges and deserts lower the defense ratings of occupying troops; hills and mountains provide additional defenses but require more fuel to move through. There are over 55 different scenarios and 16 two-player scenarios.

Source: Wikipedia, "Super Conflict: The Mideast", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

What Is This?

Dungeon World is a roleplaying game that uses sweet modern roleplaying techniques to create an old school adventure game feel.

The cool modern ideas are mostly from Apocalypse World, D. Vincent Baker’s game of a post-apocalyptic wasteland. The rollicking adventure feel is taken from editions of Dungeons and Dragons from Advanced Dungeons and Dragons through 4th Edition. Together, they make for a fast, fun, driven fantasy adventure game.

The first Apocalypse World/Dungeons and Dragons hybrid was Tony Dowler’s Apocalypse D&D. This is a continuation of Tony’s great ideas to a bigger game.

This isn’t the full Dungeon World game. Dungeon World is a complete game, [while] Dungeon World Hack requires Apocalypse World to play it.

boardgame.name: C. C. Higgins Rail Pass
boardgame.description:
C. C. Higgins Rail Pass is a railroad board game that lets you relive the excitement of a railroad executive in the heyday of rail travel.

Basically a roll-and-move game without the dice, passes may be used to facilitate free rail travel. Collect color-coded sets of rail passes as you travel the rails of North American railroad companies of 1920. Plan your routes as you race to designated payday cities utilizing the free travel from the rail passes you obtain along the way. The goal of the game is to garner the most points by combining rail passes into various sets defined by having the most passes in color categories and types of Railroads. C. C. Higgins Rail Pass is a completely luck-free strategy game that is both simple and extremely flexible in play.

boardgame.name: Feenstaub und Fabelwesen
boardgame.description:
from the back of the book

In the tradition of "Verwunschen und Verzaubert" and "Feenwälder, Zauberflüsse" this collection presents four DSA adventures, each with the subject of the work of fairies and the resulting myths, legends and fairy tales. Often these contain than a grain of truth - but caution is advised because especially in the context of the fairies nothing is quite as it seems.
"Drei Schwüre" by Muna Bering leads into the inhospitable Transysilien. Here, under the influence of the demonic rulers many stories have taken a turn into the gloom - but the heroes can make sure that this will not stay that way!
In "Fischerfest" by Carsten Pohl and Caillean Kompe we travel to the Wadden Sea coast of Nostria. Life on the dike and the vagaries of the sea play a role, as do the ruins of a lighthouse.
"Tod eines Geschichtenerzählers" by Astrid Mosler tells us again that not all is what it seems, while the heroes investigate the death of a story teller in Winhall.
"Verwunschen" by Stefan Unteregger finally plays on the edge of the dark Reichsforst, where the presence of fairies is not that unusual - but this also gives rise to many desires.

boardgame.name: Demonmaster
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

Demonmaster is a Quest for the Chronicles of Arax solo adventure game. It is a two-part Quest; the first part takes place within the pirate town of Gaxdon, while the second takes place in the wilderness beyond.

For eight days and nights you have been at sea, but your journey is nearing its end, a fact for which you are grateful. A little over a week ago you had learned of attacks on the city of Gaxdon, a place known to be a hotbed of thieves, assassins and pirates. Normally, you would avoid a place like that like the plague, but the rumours of these attacks caught your attention and prompted you to investigate.

The attacks, so the rumours said, happened every night by a horde of demons under the control of a demonmaster - an insane summoner of demons who, somehow, is able to control them with the force of their will alone. These men and women are extremely dangerous and unpredictable and are a great force of evil in the world, so you made the decision to see if these rumours were true.

You set sail from Port Bannon on the White Maiden, a merchant ship with a reputation of trafficking stolen goods. Again, this is not something you would normally do, but most respectable ships avoid Gaxdon. Without much choice, you bought passage onboard the White Maiden and set out.

During the voyage the crew tell you what they know. Each night the demons attack from outside the walls, assaulting relentlessly until the dawn. They then disappear before reappearing again as soon as the sun is down. The demonmaster is said to be hiding somewhere outside the city walls, but the exact location has not been able to be determined.

As the ship sails into the harbour you catch your first glimpse of Gaxdon. It is a rundown, ramshackle town, and you get the impression that you are not going to like it here...

boardgame.name: Greatwood Ranger
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

The Greatwood Ranger is a new Hero for you to use in the Chronicles of Arax solo adventure game.

During the Age of Golden Dreams, man, dwarf and elf lived unopposed upon Arax. Civilization flourished, with great cities and fortresses being built.

Within the Greatwood, the elves built magnificent crystal towers to live in. This towers helped focus the magical energy known as mana and aided the elves in their spell casting. In order to gain this crystal the elves had to travel the world in search for it. Thus were born the Greatwood Rangers.

The Rangers journeyed far and wide, looking for sources of the crystal that they could either claim for themselves or trade for from the other peoples of Arax. In this way they learned much about the world and its people.

And then the Age of Golden Dreams ended, and the Age of Darkness and Nightmares began.

The Greatwood was invaded by orcs from the north and undead from the south. The Rangers were called home and, instead of traveling the world, were now tasked with defending the borders of the Greatwood. Slowly but surely the forest was defiled, and its borders pushed ever inwards, though if not for the Rangers the forest home of the elves would probably have already been wiped out.

To this day the Greatwood Rangers still protect the home of the elves, though some have left the woodlands in order to journey the world once more in search of something - anything - that will help them push back the inevitable tide of darkness that threatens to engulf them.

boardgame.name: Ghostwood
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

Ghostwood is a Quest for the Chronicles of Arax solo adventure game. It is a two-part Quest; the first part takes place within the Ghostwood forest itself, while the second takes place beneath Ghostwood.

Standing outside the forest gives you an eerie feeling; after all, the name Ghostwood is well earned. Rumours of spirits and undead haunting the woodlands before you are well known throughout Arax and people avoid the area like the plague. Unfortunately you do not have that luxury.

You have been charged with the responsibility of tracking down the legendary Thunderhammer, a dwarven weapon of great power. It was stolen from the dwarfs of Valijr Keep a little over a week ago but a dwarf-turned-traitor named Brok. The once respected warrior fled with the Thunderhammer to the west, and you have managed to track him to the edge of Ghostwood.

He must have been desperate to escape to have entered the forest, you reason to yourself; either that or Brok was insane. His reasons for stealing the weapon are still unknown at this point, though bribery or outside influence are suspected.

You take a deep breath and prepare to enter Ghostwood. You have a really bad feeling about this, but the dwarfs are paying you good money; that overrides your fear of what you may find so, drawing your weapon, you begin your trek into the forest.

boardgame.name: Ajin Warrior
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

The Ajin Warrior is a new Hero for you to use in the Chronicles of Arax solo adventure game.

Far to the east of mainland Arax lies a small island empire known as Napaj. Most people know very little of this place, and this is not just due to the long distances between the mainland and the empire; the people of Napaj are notoriously secretive, and foreigners are rarely allowed inside their borders.

This is not to say the people of Napaj never leave their lands and journey to the mainland though, for this does happen on occasion. Merchants visit the port cities, bringing exotic silks, spices and foods with them.

And then there are the Ajin Warriors. These men and women belong to an organization even more secretive than normal Napaji society. So secretive, in fact, that they officially don;t even exist.

The Ajin Warriors are elite fighters who, it is said, practice mystical rites that allow them to perform super-human feats. Members of the order sometimes travel to the mainland as spies or emissaries, while at other times they are also seeking adventure or are on specific missions.

In recent times, since the beginning of the Age of Darkness and Nightmares, some Ajin Warriors have arrived on mainland Arax to help stem the tide of evil that is steadily growing and expanding.

boardgame.name: High Elf
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

The High Elf is a new Hero for you to use in the Chronicles of Arax solo adventure game.

While most of the elven people live within the trees, either in shelters built upon the ground or in specially crafted tree-houses high in the branches, some elves live a life of pure luxury.

These elves - the High Elves, as they are called - live in the great crystal towers that exist in within the Greatwood. They are great magic users and, due to the nature of these crystal towers - they focus the natural mana of the land into pools that allow those near them to cast spells of great power - they have become the pinnacle of elven spell casters.

During the Age of Golden Dreams, before the evil came to Arax, the High Elves helped shape the Greatwood and, to a lesser extent, the world around it. When the Age of Darkness and Nightmares began, they instead began to focus their magic on driving back the evil tide that began to spread throughout the world.

Alas, their efforts have been in vain. The Greatwood has been defiled on all sides and the elven people decimated. The High Elves have helped slow the forces of evil but even their immense powers cannot seem to stop them.

Desperately the High Elves seek a way to stop the armies of darkness that now seem poised to conquer Arax. Whether they will or not, only time will tell.

boardgame.name: Heart of Darkness
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

Heart of Darkness is a three-part Quest for the Chronicles of Arax solo adventure game. It consists of 40 Encounters. Part One takes part in the Bloodsands, a hot and parched desert. Part Two takes place in some sand-blasted hills within the Bloodsands, while part three takes place underground.

You are sitting in the war chamber of Lord Carse, leader of the fortified outpost known as Crimsonrock. With you are many advisors, as well as Lord Carse himself. Standing behind the Lord is a figure dressed in a hooded light brown robe, his (or her) features completely hidden.

“Thank you for answering our message,” begins Lord Carse, “and thank you for coming as quickly as you did.” You nod and smile. “We have need of someone brave and daring, such as yourself, to undertake a dangerous mission.” You hadn’t really expected anything less, so you indicate that you are listening. “This is somewhat of a secret, so we trust you will keep this to yourself.

“As you know, this outpost stands very close to the northern edge of the Bloodsands, the great desert that is home to the undead legions. Within this desert is an outcropping of hills and mountains, very tall, that is home to a race of beings whose existence has long been kept quiet. These beings, the Shin’via, as they are called, guard a sacred chamber that is home to an artifact of great - and dark - power. This artifact is said to be the heart of a demonic god, and it has the power to unmake life. Not just simply kill someone, mind you, but unmake them completely as if they had never existed.”

Lord Carse pauses to let this sink in for a few moments before indicating that the brown-robed figure should come forward. The creature lowers its hood, revealing some sort of reptilian face, with beady eyes, sandy coloured scales and a long tongue that flicks in and out like that of a snake or lizard.

“Viash here is an emissary of the Shin’via, and he has come with a dire warning,” continues Lord Carse. “It appears that the undead have learnt of the chambers the Shin’via guard and are now marching on them, ready to throw all they have at gaining the Darkheart, as the artifact is known. This cannot be allowed to happen. Will you go and stop this? Do whatever you must, but the Darkheart must remain within the chambers guarded by the Shin’via or else all of Arax is doomed.”

“I will go,” you say. “When do I leave?”

“Immediately,” replies Lord Carse. “Viash will act as your guide through the Bloodsands. Take plenty of water with you, it would not do for you to die of thirst before completing your mission.” You stand and nod and, along with Viash, prepare to leave.

boardgame.name: Dwarven Stoneguard
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

The Dwarven Stoneguard is a new Hero for you to use in the Chronicles of Arax solo adventure game.

The Dwarven Stoneguard were once the pride of the dwarven strongholds. They were elite warriors, charged with defending the strongholds from the many enemies of the dwarven people: the orc tribes of the north, the goblins from beneath the ground, and the various monsters and savage beasts that roamed the wilderness.

For the most part, they were highly successful. On only one occasion did the fortresses of the dwarf people become compromised, and that was mainly due the corrupting and poisonous magic of the goblins causing illness in many of the Stoneguard. But even then, they were able to overcome this and eject the goblins from their home.

All of this changed at the start of the Age of Darkness and Nightmares. The orc hordes attacked on masse, the goblins found new and powerful magics, and demons and undead monstrosities added to the dwarven problems. Slowly, one by one, the dwarven fortresses began to fall.

The Stoneguard, being the first line of defence for the dwarven people, were blamed for not defending their homes properly. They became maligned amongst their own people even though, in the face of overwhelming odds, they never once faltered or fled, laying down their lives for their homes.

Today, the Stoneguard continue to defend the last two dwarven fortresses left standing from their enemies. They do so with skill, bravery and resolution. Some Stoneguard have left their ancestral homes, traveling out into the wider world in the hopes of finding some sort of aid for the dwarfs. What they have found has left them in despair, yet they continue to fight, never giving up on the hope that, one day, the will push the darkness back and a new age of light will begin.

boardgame.name: Keel-Hauled!
boardgame.description:
Keel-Hauled! is a dice game for 2 to 4 players. Although the game does contain some complexity, it is relatively simple to learn. Play time for a full game of 50 points is usually less than an hour.

Players are pirates who vie for the position of Captain on a pirate ship. To to this, players must roll their dice to assemble sets that first match the number on the "Crew Dice" which represent the Cabin Boy, Ship's Cook, and First Mate. This becomes more challenging as there are limited spaces on the boat for dice sets to be placed, and the first player can change throughout the game.

The game is normally continued until one player scores 30 to 50 points, when the player with the most points overall is dubbed the new Captain of the ship.

Keel-Hauled has been discontinued, and is no longer available at The Game Crafter website.

In the game the player controls Spider-Man through six side-scrolling levels, with a member of the Sinister Six at the end of each level as a boss. The famous super-hero could jump, punch, kick, climb certain walls, shoot unlimited webs to swing on and collect web fluid to shoot square, web projectives. The levels were generally pretty straight forward side-scrolling action, although occasionally a particular item such as key or a detonator would have to be found. Each level started out with a graphic illustration of Spider-Man battling the supervillain that the player would fight as a boss.

Spider-Man has only one life (in the NES version), although you do receive one continue. While there are web cartridge icons scattered throughout certain levels, (allowing Spider-Man to shoot ten web projectiles) there are no icons available to restore energy. boardgame.name: If Badger was a Bunny
boardgame.description:
The hare and tortoise are staging a series of races! This an asymmetric 2 player climbing race game using the Decktet system. Even though the players must shed the same amount of cards, the Hare is given much more to use (and is more free to use them) at the start of the game, but the Tortoise will slowly and steadily build up her hand.

The card play like climbing games is in response to the opponent's plays, but it is also constrained because the players must always connect their plays with their developing race tracks. The winner with the best record after four races is the champion badger!

Full rules may be found on wiki.decktet.com

boardgame.name: Atari 2600 Paddle Controller
CX30
boardgame.description:
A paddle is a game controller with a round wheel and one or more fire buttons, where the wheel is typically used to control movement of the player object along one axis of the video screen. A paddle controller rotates through a fixed arc (usually about 330 degrees); it has a stop at each end.

Atari 2600 Paddle controllers come in pairs both connecting to a single controller port. These controllers also rotate just under one full rotation before hitting a hard stop. Finally, they have a picture of a tennis racquet and the word "paddle" on it. Because two controllers connect to each port and the 2600 has two controller ports, four players simultaneously can play in games that support it.

Design

The paddle wheel is usually mechanically coupled to a potentiometer, so as to generate an output voltage level varying with the wheel's angle relative to a fixed reference position. A paddle is thus an absolute position controller. That is, without any previous knowledge, the sensor can be read and the result directly indicates the position of the paddle knob. This is in contrast to a quadrature encoder-based device or "spinner".

Games

Some famous video games using paddles are Pong, Breakout, and Night Driver. The reason for the name paddles for this type of game controller is that the first game that used it, Pong, was a video game simulation of table tennis, whose racquets are commonly called paddles. Even though the simulated paddles appeared on-screen (as small line segments), it was the hand controllers used to move the line segments that actually came to bear the name.

Source: Wikipedia, "Paddle (game controller)", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

boardgame.name: Nadia of the Mysterious Seas
The Secret of Blue Water
ふしぎの海のナディア
boardgame.description:
User Summary

The title literally translates to "Nadia of the Mysterious Seas", although the English title used for the series by the Japanese is "The Secret of Blue Water".

Taken from the manual:

[original japanese]

汝は冒険者か。　危険という名の滝をくぐり抜け、その奥に、伝説の正体を求める者か。ならば、我を求めよ。

時に１８８９年。

今から１００年ほど前の昔、沈みゆくノーチラス、キングはとある無人島に漂着し、数々の困難を克服しながら、子供だけの気ままなその日暮らしをしていました。 しかし、ジャンがコツコツと築きあげた一大科学文明も一夜の嵐によってあつけなく崩壊してしまったのです。 ところが「禍福はあざなえる縄のごとし」の例えどおりに、嵐はジャン達の前に巨大な島も運んできてくれたのです。 その島で懐かしい、エアトンやグランヂイス、サンソン、ハンソンの３人組に再会したジャン達は食料が豊富なグランヂイス達の島に移り住むことに決めました。

やがて、この島にはおかしなことがいくつもあることがわかります。 中でも最大の謎は、この島は動いているということでした。 動く島での生活にも落ち着いたある日、この島は不思議な島の前で止まってしまいます。 ジャン達はその島に上陸し、調べてみることにしました。 この島には一体どんな秘密があるのでしょうか。 そして、ナヂイアは一体何を考えて生きているのでしょうか。

[translated]

Art thou an adventurer? Someone who would know the truth of the legend no matter the danger? If so, follow!

Year: 1889

100 years ago after the sinking of the Nautilus, the castaways, along with King, after many hard times, were living a carefree life on a deserted island. However, the island "civilization" that Jean had built piece by piece using his knowledge of science, was destroyed overnight by a storm. "Sometimes from misfortune comes luck" for the storm also carried a huge island before Jean and the others. On this island, Jean and the others met up with their old friends Aryton, Grandis, Samson, and Hanson. The food was abundant so they decided to stay.

Over time they noticed many strange things about the island. The strangest of all was that island was moving! One day after they had all settled down to life on a moving island, the island stops in front of a new and mysterious island. Jean and the others decided to land on this new island and explore it. What kind of secret will they discover on this new island? Meanwhile, Nadia is thinking to herself "Now what?!"

boardgame.name: Powers & Worlds
boardgame.description:
From Introduction:

Powers and Worlds is a bit of an anecdotal behind-the-scenes documentary mixed in with a "how to" guidebook. We'd been asked by the fans to give some help in designing Pulse-wielding powers in various settings, and it was something we really wanted to help out with. But wow! What a tall order! Of all the magic in all the worlds - how could we tackle such a huge task?

While creating the Weapons and Worlds list, the answer came to us; we'd do it the same way - by example. And that's how Powers and Worlds came about. Over the years of play testing different settings with the second edition Suzerain rules, we'd designed over a thousand feats, many of them Pulse powers. By taking some of those examples and talking about them, we hope you get a feel for the ways in which you can develop your own. We only scratch the surface in these pages - the rest is up to you!

boardgame.name: Dualism
boardgame.description:
Dualism is a fascinating puzzle game about polarity. It features 160 levels ranging from easy to hard.

Dualism requires an iPad with iOS 4.2 or higher.

You draw one continuous line on the board and each stone the line touches, will switch its color. Black to white and vice versa.

To finish a level you have to make sure each stone in each row has the same color. But be aware, different rows can have different colors!

Dualism features over 160 challenging levels. 100 levels are included for free. Enough to keep you hooked for hours.

A 10 level tutorial is included, so you can learn to play Dualism hands on.

Dualism is Game Center enabled, so you can share all your solved levels with your friends online!

boardgame.name: Doom's Knight
Dooms Knight
boardgame.description:
You’ve been punitively posted to Mars after assaulting your commanding officer, who ordered your unit to fire upon civilians. The Martian marine base acts as security for AGM corporation (AGM), a multi-planetary conglomerate, which is performing secret experiments with teleportation by creating gateways between the two moons of Mars, Phobos and Deimos.

Phobos is considered by space marines to be the dullest assignment imaginable: "with no action for eighty million miles, your day consisted of suckin' sand and watchin' flicks in the rec room." This all changes when the AGM experiments go horribly wrong.

Computer systems on Phobos malfunction, Deimos disappears entirely, and "something fragging evil" starts pouring out of the gateway, killing or possessing all AGM personnel. Responding to a frantic distress call from the overrun scientists, the Martian marine unit is quickly sent to Phobos to investigate, where you’re left to guard the hangar with only a pistol while the rest of the group proceeds inside. Over the course of the next few hours, you hear assorted garbled radio messages, gunfire, and screams, followed by silence: "Seems your buddies are dead…or WORSE…"

As the last man standing, your mission is to fight through the entire onslaught of demonic enemies by yourself in order to keep them from attacking Earth.


*** *** ***




If you liked Doom, you'd like Doom's Knight. All new 36 new levels and new sound track will put you in the middle of the action.

boardgame.name: Derelicts of Sin: Heresy
boardgame.description:
Derelicts of Sin: Heresy is the first in a series of games revolving around the Derelicts of Sin and the dark past of the Theocratic Council.

Heresy revolves around Kyle Mason, the sole survivor of a terrible act of sabotage. Hoping to find oxygen before he asphyxiates, Kyle limps his sabotaged ship into a forbidden Cursed Zone called "the Wreckage." There, he boards one of the Derelicts of Sin, the Heresy, desperate to find the supplies he needs to survive and return home.

This solo game seeks to recreate the feel of classic text-based adventures. The player takes on the role of engineer Kyle Mason. Oxygen is used as action points to move, open locked doors, restore power, etc. The player begins on the Airlock tile. As he or she explores the ship, additional tiles are drawn randomly and added to the ship. These tiles provide instructions on how to further advance, reveal the items that can be found in the new room, and detail the the puzzle(s), if any, that must be solved in order to win the game.

In the current version, a player sheet is used to track the player's physical and mental states (which affect the player's ability to search the ship and perform various actions), as well as the player's oxygen level and inventory. Another optional version is in development that will use chart tiles and tokens to track these things.

As the player explores the ship, he or she will find data cards that gradually reveal the terrible fate of the Heresy and its passengers and crew. They also provide victory points that are key to obtaining the specific ending a player desires. Without sufficient victory points, players will lose when they end the game, so it's important to find as many data cards as possible.

This game was developed as part of the Solitaire Print-and-Play Contest at http://boardgamegeek.com/thread/644090/solitaire-print-and-p....

boardgame.name: Ash
boardgame.description:
These are strange days for Aghaus. By order of the Magistrate, the Royal Guard is to assemble for deployment in two days’ time. It has been years since I last left the capital, and further still that I can remember such a command being issued! But what need is there for a Royal Guard, when no King sits upon the throne? Though my oath binds me to his service, the Magistrate is not my liege. He rules in the absence of a rightful heir.

My men await their orders; they too are uneasy. It is for their sake that I stay my tongue, and place my faith in the Almighty that my fears are unfounded.

Tomorrow, we make for the East.

–Captain Creval of the Royal Guard, in the 895th year of our Empire

18 months in the making, Ash, SRRN’s full length RPG for the iPhone and iPod Touch is finally ready for release.

Designed exclusively for the iPhone, Ash is an original turn-based RPG, featuring an all-new, intuitive touch-based interface, lush visuals licensed from Enterbrain, beautifully orchestrated music, and a wonderfully compelling story.

Ash tells the story of two mercenaries on the fringes of the Empire of Aghaus, a once-great kingdom now fallen into ruin after the death of its king five years prior. When a routine contract takes an unexpected turn, the two men are gradually embroiled in a conflict that consumes the entire continent—and brings to light the mercenaries’ mysterious pasts.

Source: The Game Website.

boardgame.description:
Game Overview

In Atlantida you control a faction of the people of Atlantis that, after a series of catastrophes that turn their once glorious civilization to a semi-barbaric state, must move to the safety of the continent to avoid perish in the island inevitable collapse.
There are 13 turns, in which you must explore the island to gather resources, develop your city and discover technologies and advances in order to be able to send your population to safety. The winner is the first to save all her people or the most efficient to save them in the moment the island collapses.

Game Development

Even though the Atlantida already works as intended and the general idea is defined, it is still subject to changes. The game was developed directly for the yucata.de website, aiming to benefit from multiple plays which can provide a fair amount of players' feedback and suggestions. boardgame.name: Fosfofou
boardgame.description:
A luminous observation game: The cards all look the same at first glance, so it's not so easy to pair them up.

Object of the game is create as many pairs as You can. Players mix the cards then place them on the table with the "5 geometric forms" side facing upwards. All the players play at the same time. Once the signal is given, each player looks at the cards and tries to find identical pairs. As soon as a player thinks he has created a pair, he takes two cards, places them in front of him and continues to search for other pairs. But watch out for mistakes as the cards are very similar!In fact, all the cards contain the 5 same geometric shapes; only their location differs from one card to the other. You are not allowed to touch the cards except to finally take them!

Game ends when there are no more cards in the centre of the table, or it does not seem possible to create another pair (if the players have taken incorrect pairs), each player checks the pairs that he has created. Winner is the player with the most correct pairs.

Components:

48 luminous cards

boardgame.name: Zed by Dawn
boardgame.description:
The world as you knew it has collapsed, flesh eating horrors from your worst nightmares walk the earth, and you're low on ammo..

Welcome to Zed by Dawn.

Object:
Zed by Dawn is a print-and-play solo survival horror dice and card game in the world of Zed Run!!! Before the Citystates, before the Gameshow, there were survivors that tirelessly fought the undead hordes; ZbD pits you against a world gone mad.

Zbd's Combat system requires the player to meet or exceed a number of successes that match the encounters target number, using a custom set of six-sided dice.

Each roll whether it be all six dice or just one die will use the survivors precious resources, Fatigue is use to perform melee attacks, ammo is used to perform ranged attacks and if your survivor is ever out of these resources, they cannot use the matching weapon.

Weapons will lower the needed number of successes to defeat encounters.

Items will be used to replenish your survivors resource pools.

Events encountered will hinder your advancement.

Survive to draw the last card in the ZbD deck and made it through the night. But what will tomorrow bring.

You must manage your resources, acquire supplies, and defeat an endless army of the walking dead; your only goal is to survive.

What you need to play
72 ZbD Cards
6 Survivor Cards
3 Resource Tracking dice (d20)
6 Combat dice (d6)

boardgame.name: Pirate Polo
boardgame.description: Pirate Polo is a frantic live-action game for 2 - 4 "pirates". The game is played using a mini-trampoline as the playing surface. Each player has 5 dice of a single, unique color. In the center of the mini-trampoline is set a heavy, non-fragile cereal bowl. The players space themselves evenly around the mini-trampoline and place all five of their dice on the game surface in front of them. Each player has a polo mallet (at times also known as a serving spoon). On the starting signal, all players strike underneath the mini-trampoline with their polo mallet to try to propel their dice into the bowl. The first player to get all 5 dice in the bowl is the winner. This game is an alternative to the difficult to obtain Piratenbillard.

boardgame.name: Traveller Set 2 - Imperial Marines
boardgame.description:
User summary:

57 15mm full-color front and back sided folding miniatures plus a number of small counters with full color weapons.

From the Instruction sheet:

Full-color miniatures for all your games...with no bending, breaking or painting hassle...at a fraction of the cost of lead figures!

Each CARDBOARD HEROES figure is shown in both front and back views, and folds to form its own base (or you can use our optional plastic bases). Collect all the sets - and put a whole army in your pocket! They're perfect for travel and quick games, or for a whole campaign.

This is Traveller Set 2: Imperial Marines. The set contains 3 identical cards, each with 19 different figures: officers, sentries, troops in undress uniform, troops in camouflage battledress, and troops in Imperial Marine maroon urban battledress, plus extra weapon and equipment counters.

Also available now are Player Characters and Zhodani sets for Traveller. Watch for more releases soon, including Vargr and armored vehicles.

boardgame.name: Traveller Set 3 - Zhodani
boardgame.description:
User summary:

57 15mm full-color front and back sided folding miniatures plus a number of small counters with full color weapons.

From the Instruction sheet:

Full-color miniatures for all your games...with no bending, breaking or painting hassle...at a fraction of the cost of lead figures!

Each CARDBOARD HEROES figure is shown in both front and back views, and folds to form its own base (or you can use our optional plastic bases). Collect all the sets - and put a whole army in your pocket! They're perfect for travel and quick games, or for a whole campaign.

This is Traveller Set 3: Zhodani. The set contains 3 identical cards, each with 19 different figures: officers (nobles and intendants), troops (proles) in ordinary uniforms, troops in camouflage battledress, and battledress troops in standard Zhodani black. Also included: extra weapon/gear counters.

Also available now are Player Character and Imperial Marine sets for Traveller. New releases will include Vargr and armored vehicles.

boardgame.name: Escape
boardgame.description:
From the front cover:

The Adventure is designed for characters of virtually any background in the employ of a merchant company based in the Reavers' Deep sector. Characters should possess a mix of skills spanning many fields.

From the back cover:

Situation: Hopeless! Alone on an untamed world.... imprisoned by warrior Aslan .... the human expedition on Htalrea faces impossible odds as they strive to win free from their alien captors. It will take every bit of skill and luck the adventurers can muster to out fox the Aslan warriors and escape.

Escape is a folio adventure approved for use with Traveller, GDW's original role-playing game of Science-Fiction adventure in the far future. Written by J. Andrew Keith, Escape picks up where his earlier folio Trading Team (published by Marischal Adventures) left off.... and launches a new line of SEEKER folios that link together to form an ongoing Traveller campaign.
